natural problem: Compute the domain of the real-valued function \[f(x)=\sqrt{1-\sqrt{2-\sqrt{x}}}.\]
natural solution: For the contents of the innermost square root to be nonnegative, we must have $x\geq 0$.

To satisfy the middle square root, we must have  $$2-\sqrt{x}\geq 0\Rightarrow 4\geq x.$$ Finally, the outermost square root requires $$1-\sqrt{2-\sqrt{x}}\geq 0.$$ This gives us $$1\geq 2-\sqrt{x}\Rightarrow x\geq 1.$$ Combining our inequalities, we get ${1\leq x\leq 4}$, or $x \in \boxed{[1, 4]}$ in interval notation.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x f :: real
assumes h0 : "f x = sqrt (1 - sqrt (2 - sqrt x))"
shows  "1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the domain of the real-valued function \[f(x)=\sqrt{1-\sqrt{2-\sqrt{x}}}.\] The final Answer is [1, 4]
 ### Proof
 For the contents of the innermost square root to be nonnegative, we must have $x\geq 0$.
 To satisfy the middle square root, we must have  $$2-\sqrt{x}\geq 0\Rightarrow 4\geq x.$$ Finally, the outermost square root requires $$1-\sqrt{2-\sqrt{x}}\geq 0.$$ This gives us $$1\geq 2-\sqrt{x}\Rightarrow x\geq 1.$$ Combining our inequalities, we get ${1\leq x\leq 4}$, or $x \in \boxed{[1, 4]}$ in interval notation.
 *)

theorem
fixes x f :: real
assumes h0 : "f x = sqrt (1 - sqrt (2 - sqrt x))"
shows  "1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the range of values for $x$ such that the function $f(x) = \sqrt{1 - \sqrt{2 - \sqrt{x}}}$ is defined. The final answer is $1 \leq x \leq 4$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sqrt (1 - sqrt (2 - sqrt x))"
shows  "Domain f = {x | x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 4}"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 To satisfy the middle square root, we must have  $$2-\sqrt{x}\geq 0\Rightarrow 4\geq x.$$ Finally, the outermost square root requires $$1-\sqrt{2-\sqrt{x}}\geq 0.$$ This gives us $$1\geq 2-\sqrt{x}\Rightarrow x\geq 1.$$ Combining our inequalities, we get ${1\leq x\leq 4}$, or $x \in \boxed{[1, 4]}$ in interval notation.
 *)

fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sqrt (1 - sqrt (2 - sqrt x))"
shows  "Domain f = {x | x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 4}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the domain of the function $f(x) = \sqrt{1 - \sqrt{2 - \sqrt{x}}}$, where x is a real number. The domain is the set of all $x$ such that $1 \le x \le 4$.
